thread.title: A monkey wrench in cities' panhandling laws
thread.title_full: A monkey wrench in cities' panhandling laws - The Denver Post

author: The Denver Post Editorial Board
title: A monkey wrench in cities' panhandling laws
text:
Denver and many cities' attempts to create a comfortable and non-threatening atmosphere for residents and visitors just got harder with a federal court ruling this week that rolled back panhandling rules in Grand Junction.
U.S. District Court Judge Christine Arguello basically said there is no compelling reason for many popular municipal restrictions on panhandling and that the oft-cited rationale provided by local government, which is public safety, is bogus.
The judge is right that if cities are going to restrict speech based on content — someone asking for money, for example — they have to muster powerful arguments on their side. And as she also emphasized, the U.S. Supreme Court this year seems to have taken a new tack on content-based restrictions of free speech. It did so in a major case involving outdoor signs and then suggested the same reasoning applied to panhandling, making it harder for cities to crack down.
But Arguello's ruling nevertheless fails to recognize the inherently unsettling nature of certain forms of panhandling. Let's say you are accosted by a panhandler in a parking garage late at night while trying to retrieve cash at an ATM, and he makes repeated requests for money while you try to stuff your bills away.
Many people might feel somewhat intimidated — which is why Denver, for example, currently outlaws panhandling at night and within 20 feet of an ATM, among other restrictions. And yet the judge declared that cities cannot prohibit multiple requests for money, requests made within 20 feet of an ATM, or panhandling after dark.
She says, for example, "There is no indication that panhandling at night ... is inherently dangerous or threatening to the public."
